quote: First officer's log, stardate 41986.0.   The captain has left the ship for   a conference and we are awaiting   his return. It is unusual for us   to be motionless, and a unique   experience for everyone concerned.
This is quite intriguing. It is   transmitting a carrier signal on   a frequency which has not been used   for centuries.
Is there a message?
None. Just the carrier, possibly   intended for encoded computer or   telemetry information.
I have never seen a space vehicle   like it.

Strictly speaking, it is not a   "space vehicle." It appears to   be a satellite, similar in its   rudimentary design to those which   orbited Earth in the late   twentieth and early twenty-first   centuries.
Three hundred years ago.       Then there probably aren't any   life signs?
None.
The power is solar... quite   primitive. There is however   minimum life support.
I wonder how it got out here.   If it was in orbit around Earth,   even at maximum impulse -- and   there's no way it could travel   any faster, it would have taken   a dozen centuries to get here.
At its present speed and heading,   the vehicle will eventually enter   the Kazis Binary system and will   certainly be destroyed.
Sir, I could attach a tractor beam   and adjust its heading.

I think not, Mister Worf. It's just   a piece of space debris. If we   weren't sitting here waiting for   the captain, we wouldn't have even   noticed it. Leave it be. Let   nature take its course. How long   until Captain Picard returns?
The last communication indicated   it would be several hours.
Commander, request permission to   investigate this vehicle.
Why, Data? It's just a derelict.
It is a piece of history. The   opportunity to examine such an   ancient vehicle does not come   around very often, and as you   pointed out, we do have the time.
All right, Data. But be ready   to beam back before the captain   returns.
Thank you, sir.
Lieutenant Worf -- go with him.
Aye, sir.
Minimal oxygen atmosphere.       An ancient solar generator,   still operating.
Computer -- status report.
Computer...
In the late twentieth century,   computers were not voice activated,   Worf.

Notice the readouts -- dials,   needle machines, gauges.   Remarkable what they used three   centuries ago. The on-board   computers have ceased functioning.   I may be able to download this old   style disk drive back to the   Enterprise.
It must be sealed -- probably   with age. I will blast it open.
Not necessary.
Data, this is Riker. What   have you found?
scene: 10   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: Very little so far.
scene: 10   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: I have picked up the captain's   shuttle.
scene: 10   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: E.T.A.?
scene: 10   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: Twelve minutes, sir.
scene: 10   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: Alert Main Shuttle Bay.
scene: 10   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: Aye, sir.
scene: 10   INT. ENTERPRISE - MAIN BRIDGE (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: The seal was broken and the   environment has been corrupted.
Here's another.
This one is empty.
It has been forced open and the   occupant removed.
Commander. Look at this.
Has she been frozen for an   extended journey?
If that were the purpose, there   would be evidence of a more   sophisticated monitoring system.   This container is designed solely   for refrigeration.
What is the destination?
I do not believe they were going   anywhere. This vehicle should   still be in Earth orbit.

There is no way it could break   orbit and travel this distance   on its own power. Not in three   hundred years -- not in three   thousand. Some intelligent lifeform   must have brought it to   this section of the galaxy.
(indicating the crypts     with the shriveled     forms)   These crypts were opened.    (indicating the empty     crypts)   The occupants in those were taken.
Why take some of them, destroy   others, and leave her apparently   untouched?
Perhaps they learned all they   could from the others. We may   never know.
The captain's shuttle is   approaching Main Shuttle Bay.
Enterprise, this is the captain.   Number One, I want to get underway   as soon as the shuttle is secure.
Aye, sir. We will make all   preparations.       Commander Data, return to the   Enterprise -- immediately.
We have run into an unusual   situation here. There are people   on-board. Frozen.
Frozen. How many?
Three. What should I do? The   vehicle has suffered severe   damage. Most of the systems   have failed.
scene: 15   INT. DERELICT - THE SECOND ROOM (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: Are you recommending they be   transferred to the Enterprise?
scene: 15   INT. DERELICT - THE SECOND ROOM (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: I do not think we should leave   them here. With your permission,   sir, we will be returning with   three containers.
scene: 15   INT. DERELICT - THE SECOND ROOM (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: Whatever you do, do it quickly.
scene: 15   INT. DERELICT - THE SECOND ROOM (INTERCUT AS NEEDED)

quote: Number One, I want a meeting on   the Observation Deck. Mister La   Forge, set course zero-five-eight,   mark nine-seven-three.
Aye -- laying in the course now.       Captain, those coordinates will   take us to the Neutral Zone.
That's correct Mister La Forge, warp   factor eight.
Warp eight.
Engage. Mister La Forge, you have   the bridge.
Two Federation outposts in Sector   three-zero have been destroyed.   There has been no communication   with any Federation starbases in   Sector three-one since stardate   41903.2.
Romulans.
That is the assumption.
There's been no direct contact   with the Romulans since the Tomed   Incident.

The question is: Why here? Why   now? What's their objective, if   indeed they have one? For half   a century there's barely a whisper   about them and now for no apparent   reason they seem to be back with   a roar. Why?
Almost everything we know about   them is based on rumor and   conjecture.
The strategic decision is to send   one ship.
The Enterprise.
Yes.
There is a risk. We could get   out there and find ourselves   greatly over-matched.
True enough -- it is a gamble.
This first encounter... coming   so suddenly after all this time.   There's a very good chance it's   a setup.
Perhaps the Romulans are probing.   They want to see how we react.
Captain, we should expect   hostilities.

Prepare as always. If force is   needed we will use it, but that   will mean we have failed. Our   goal here is to establish some   kind of relations with the   Romulans -- failing that -- to   convince them of our resolve and   to do this without resorting to   force. Right now, the general   feeling is that they are seeking   a confrontation. They may want   to test themselves in battle   against a Federation starship to   gauge how much we have advanced.   Personally, I think it is   possible they have different   motives altogether based on needs   which we have not identified.   If that's the case... I must know   it.       Counselor -- I will need a complete   profile on them.
There is limited information, but   I will prepare something.
Data. Extrapolate for me the   logical progression of their   technical advancement;   specifically, but not restricted   to -- weapons.
Aye, sir.
I want this thought through   completely. Anticipate, as much   as you can, all the possible   permutations.
Computer, how long before we   arrive at the Neutral Zone?
Nineteen hours, twenty-eight   minutes.
We will reassemble in six hours.   Let's be smart. No surprises.   I would much rather outthink them,   than outfight them. Questions?
Captain.       Doctor Crusher said she would like   to talk with you, when you   finished your meeting.
Thank you.       Doctor Crusher, this is the   captain.
Oh, good. Captain, could you   possibly join me in Sickbay?
I would not ask you if it wasn't   important.
I will be right there.       Take the Conn, Number One. I   won't be long.
What is it, Doctor?
It's the people from the capsule.
Capsule? People? What people?
The people Data beamed over.
I wasn't aware he had.
Well, he did and they were frozen.   I thawed them.
You what?
I didn't know what else to do.   The crypts in which they had been   frozen were literally falling   apart. It was either that...   or...
What's their condition?

Right now they are all sleeping.   Each of them needed minor medical   attention... minor "now", but   "then" their conditions were   obviously terminal. One had a   heart problem, another had an   advanced case of emphysema and   extensive liver damage. But the   most surprising thing, is that   each of them had been frozen after   they died.
After they died?

Exactly. Cryonics. It was a   kind of fad in the late twentieth   century. People feared dying.   It terrified them. At the moment   of death, they would be frozen,   so that later... some time in the   future, when presumably medical   science had a cure for whatever   killed them, they would be thawed   back to life, healed and sent on   about their business.
Well, for this group, apparently   it worked.
Lieutenant Commander Data, please   report to Sickbay -- immediately.
Permission to leave the bridge.
Granted.
I am never critical of any member   of my staff being curious, but...   the timing is just so...
I could not leave them there,   Captain. The condition of the   vehicle was deteriorating.
But, Data -- they were already   dead. I mean... what more could   have happened to them?
I see your point, Captain, but   at the time...
You're right -- under the   circumstances I would have done   exactly the same.
When they arrived... what was I   supposed to do? Not help them?
My question is: What do we do   with them now?
What are the options?
We cannot go back and return them   to their ship.
We can't refreeze them.
They are alive now, so we have   to treat them as living human   beings.
Alive and well, just waiting to   be awakened.
I have them sedated but they   should be up and about as soon   as possible.
Well...
Then, there really is no choice.
None that I can see.
Before you wake them, I want   Security here.       Mister Worf, report to Sickbay.
... Welcome to the twenty-fourth   century.
I was able to retrieve some   information from the ancient disk   I removed from the module's   computer. Based on that...
Her name is Clare Raymond, age   thirty-five; occupation,   homemaker... must be some kind   of construction work.
She died of an embolism. It   probably happened very suddenly,   otherwise her physical condition   was excellent.
His name is Ralph Offenhouse, age   sixty-three; occupation,   financier.
Advanced cardiomyopathy,   inoperable at the time, but easily   correctable now. He must have   known for some time his condition   was terminal.
Much of his file could not be   retrieved. His name is L. Q.   "Sonny" Clemonds. Apparently his   occupation had something to do   with music.
There was marked deterioration   of every system in his body.   Probably due to massive chemical   abuse. Unbelievable.
That sounds like someone who hated   life -- yet he had himself frozen   so presumably he could go through   it all again.
Fear. Too afraid to live... too   scared to die.
Doctor, this seems to be a   situation more suited to your   talents. I will leave it in your   hands.
I'll be on the bridge.

I know you have a lot of   questions, but I would like you   to wait. You are feeling a   certain amount of disorientation.   In a little while it should pass;   then we can fully discuss what   has happened. Nurse Wright will   furnish you with anything you   need.
Not so fast. Is this part of the   service or is it extra?
I think it would be best if...
I demand to know the cost of   anything you do before the   procedure is approved.
I have no idea what you're talking   about.    (then, mostly for the     others)   Just take it slowly. Everything   is fine. Worf, would you show   them to the guest quarters.
This way.
Number One, kindly take charge   of our guests until we have time   to decide what we are going to do   with them.
Aye, sir.
... and keep them out of my way.
(requesting to join     Riker)   Sir?
I know this is all very confusing   to you so I'll attempt to   explain. First -- you are on the   starship -- USS Enterprise.
American?
No -- we are a vessel of the United   Federation of Planets. Earth is   a member.
What year is this?
By your calendar... two thousand   three hundred sixty-four.
What?       My heart? Is it...
It's perfectly fine. In fact,   you are all now in excellent   health.
I made it... It worked. I never   believed this was...
What's that?
An android.
You mean a robot?
Actually there is a distinct   difference between a robot and   an android.
And him? The one I saw before   with the... head.
She means Worf.
Oh, he's a Klingon, and that   requires a little more   explanation.
Guys... listen. I paid some idiot   a lot of money to freeze me when   I died. I need to hear the   words... Am I alive?
Oh, yes... absolutely.
And the liver that was about to   explode in my face.
Perfectly sound.
Great...
(who has remained     confused through it     all)   Excuse me. Would someone tell   me what's going on?
Well... About three hundred and   seventy years ago you died of a   massive embolism.
I don't remember anything about   it.
You and the others were frozen.
Cryonics -- you know... freeze you   now... heal you later.
I've heard about it; I just never   paid it much mind. How did we   get here?
Why were you in a module?
The whacko who sold me this scam   said that by putting us in orbit   there would be no chance of brown   out.
Several cryonics companies had   fallen into disrepute because of   power failures which adversely   affected their refrigeration   system. Their stocks were   severely depressed.

The whole deal was a long shot...   but I figured... what the hell,   might as well give them the dough   instead of leaving it to my   ex-wives.       But you know, son, I figured it   was just so much hooey.
Hooey? Accessing.       Ah, as in malarkey... jive...   bull... hogwash... an   intentional fabrication.
There you go, now you got it.
If you didn't contract for this,   who did?
It must have been Donald -- my   husband. If it was new and   foolish, he'd have popped for it.   Well, I'll say this. It's the   first thing he ever bought into   that worked.
I, for one, never had a doubt.   My stock in this company must have   split a dozen times by now.
Actually the process of cryonics   was never more than a fad, and   did not continue much beyond the   mid-twenty-first century.
I need to make a phone call as   soon as possible.
A phone call?
I have provided for myself. I   have a substantial portfolio.   It's critical I check on it. Let   the bank know that I am alive and   well.
That's ah... going to be a little   difficult right at the moment.
Do you at least have a copy of The   Wall Street Journal?
I think we should take the   doctor's advice and go slowly.   Get adjusted to your new... ah...   whatever, and then we'll talk to   the captain.
As you know, there is very little   available on the Romulans
Anything will help.

They seem to be creatures of   extremes. One moment violent   beyond description, the next --   tender. They're related to the   Vulcans but as each developed,   their differences grew wider.   They are intensely curious. Their   belief in their own superiority   is beyond arrogance. For some   reason they have exhibited a   fascination with humans and that   fascination, more than anything   else, has kept the peace. One   other thing, they will not   initiate. They will wait for   you to commit yourself.
Counterpunches...       Thank you, Counselor. This is   quite helpful.
I don't know about you all... but   me -- I'm going to find the bar.   After all of this -- I need me a   drink.
There is nothing of that nature   on board the Enterprise.
No bars?! Don't tell me that,   son. Well, where's the   restaurant? I'm so hungry.
We have food stations.    (he indicates the     computer)   Simply tell the computer what you   want and it will be provided.
Where do you eat it?
Why... here... or anywhere. We're   not that structured.
Now what?
Talk.

I'd like me a thick Kansas City   steak - country fried potatoes   -- a mess of greens -- and... Oh,   hell... forget all of that. Let   me have a martini - -straight up...   two olives.       ... for the vitamins.
Is there something wrong?

Wrong? Only that your computer   here fixed just about the best   martini I have ever had.       I just might get to like this   place. Let's see if the Braves   are on. How do you turn on this   here teevee?
Teevee?
Yeah, boob-tube... you know. I'd   like to find out how the Braves   are doin' after all this time.   Probably still finding ways to   lose.
Oh -- I think he means television,   sir.
Or maybe catch up on the soaps.
That particular form of entertainment   did not last much beyond the year   Two Thousand Forty.
So, what do you guys do? I mean,   you don't drink -- no teevee -- kind   of boring, isn't it?
Number One.
Riker here.
Would you and Mister Data report   to the bridge?
On the way.
With whom were you speaking?
The captain.
Ah... good. Tell him I would like   to see him as soon as it's   convenient.
What is going to happen to us?   Do we stay here with you? Do we   go back to Earth?
That will be up to the captain.
Well, get him in here. I have   to phone Geneva right away about   my accounts. The interest alone   could be enough to buy even this   ship.
The Yankee's right. Let's get   the big boy in here.
I'll pass on your request. Now,   if you'll excuse us.
Duty calls -- hey, I understand...       ... come back later -- you and me   can find us a couple of   low-mileage pit woffies, and help   them build a memory.
What is to be done with them?
I don't know.
Commander. What is a   "low-mileage-pit-woffie"?
This time you have me, Data. I   haven't a clue.
These are not like any other   humans I have ever encountered.   I find them fascinating.
From what I have already seen   of our "guests", there is very   little to redeem them. In fact,   it makes me wonder, how our   species ever survived the   twenty-first century.
Report.
We are six hours from the Neutral   Zone. I have been unable to   establish communications with any   Federation colony or station in   this vicinity.
How many outposts are there in   this sector?
Nine.
I think we should go on the   presumption that they've all   been destroyed.
By the Romulans?
It fits their historical pattern.
Since there has been no contact   with the Romulans for fifty-three   years, seven months, eighteen   days, we must consider that the   information we do have, is out   of date.
The positive side of that is their   information about us is also out   of date. Captain, I believe that   lack of information is what this   is all about.
Continue, Number One.
In my opinion, the Romulans want   a confrontation... specifically   against us.
The Enterprise?

Not by name; but yes, against us.   They know the Federation will send   their best -- this will be a   perfect chance for them to learn   firsthand, how much we have   advanced in both technology, and   technique.
And your recommendation.
I don't know if I have a specific   recommendation. Perhaps we should   consider taking the initiative.
I agree with Commander Riker.   We may only have one opportunity;   we should seize it.
Data.
That strategy is built on a single   premise. The hostile intent of   the Romulans. If the premise is   sound, so is the proposal.
If their intention isn't hostile,   what is it?
Captain Picard?
This is the captain, to whom am   I speaking?
Ralph Offenhouse. Captain, I need   to talk to you.
What's going on here, Number One?   Did you give him permission to   contact me?
No, sir. He must have seen me   use the com panel.
Listen, Mister Offenhouse. We   are in a very important conference   right now and...
I am sick and tired of being put   off by you and your staff. This   is the worst run ship I have ever   been on. You could take some   lessons from the Q-E Two. Now   that's an efficient operation.
Data -- identify -- what's the   Q-E-Two?
It was a passenger liner which   mostly traveled Earth's Atlantic   Ocean during the late twentieth   and early twenty-first centuries.
He's comparing the Enterprise to   a cruise ship.
I demand you see me.

... I think I have been very, very   patient, especially under the   circumstances and considering what   I paid for this procedure, but   frankly enough is enough. I   demand a phone, or a radio   whatever you have. I must contact   my...
(continuing; off balance     for a beat)   ...lawyers.
I am Captain Picard.
Excellent.
Now, we'll be able to get some   things straight.
Indeed we will. Those com panels   are for official ship business.
If they are so important, why   don't they need an "executive   key"?
Aboard a starship, that is not   necessary. We are all capable   of exercising self-control. You   will refrain from using them.
Now just a minute.
We are involved in a   very serious and potentially   dangerous situation.
I'm sure that whatever it is seems   very important to you. My   situation is far more critical.
I do not think you are fully aware   of your situation, or the time   which has passed.

Believe me, I'm fully cognizant   of where I am, and when. It is   simply that I have more to protect   than a man in your position could   possibly imagine. No offense,   but a military career has never   been considered upwardly mobile.   I must contact my lawyer.
Your lawyer has been dead for   centuries.
Yes, of course I know that, but   he was a full partner with a very   important firm. Rest assured the   firm is still operating.

That's what this is all about...   A lot has changed in three hundred   years. People are no longer   obsessed with the accumulation of   "things". We have eliminated hunger,   want, the need for possessions.   We have grown out of our infancy.
You've got it wrong. It's never   been about "possessions" - it's   about power.
Power to do what?
To control your life, your   destiny.
That kind of control is an   illusion.
Really -- I'm here aren't I? I   should be dead and I'm not.   That's what money did for me.   That's the kind of power I'm   talking about.
What is it?
I don't know. It just started   and I can't stop. I keep   thinking about my boys.
Counselor Troi, report to the   guest lounge.
Captain, we are approaching   Science Station Delta Zero-Five.
Slow to impulse... I'm on my way.
Say, Captain -- I need to see that   pretty Doctor of yours.
I will inform her.
Captain. I didn't mean to come   on so strong. I've built my life   on knowing what's going on. For   the first time -- I'm completely   out of touch -- it makes me crazy.   Can you understand?
It's the first thing you've said   that I do understand. I'll see   what I can do. But please... stay   off the com panel.
Counselor, get those people under   control. We cannot afford this   continuing distraction.
Yes, sir.
Hello -- my name is Deanna.
They sent you here to settle me   down.
I'm the ship's counselor and I   thought you might want to talk.
The local shrink.
I'm sorry, I do not know that   term.
It doesn't matter.
You are feeling profoundly sad.

Can't stop crying. I miss my   sons, and then I think... I'm   here, but they are gone. Donald   -- he's my husband. I love that   man but, good intentions aside,   he'd mess up a free lunch. Why   in the world he ever decided to   do this...
He must have thought you would   have wanted it.

I can tell you exactly what   happened. He couldn't think about   going on alone. I died, but he   couldn't face it. So he figured   if he had me frozen, then in his   mind I wasn't really gone. Crazy,   huh? But you have to know Donald.
I'm in a world of strangers. I   wish I knew what happened to my   children. Did they get married,   did they have kids...
Let's see if we can find out.
Computer - this is Counselor Troi.   Request personal history on...   What are their names?
Tommy -- he's eight, and Eddie's   five.
Full names -- Date and place of   birth.
They were born in Secaucus -   that's in Jersey.       Can this really work? Can this   tell me what happened to them?
There has to be a record   somewhere. There is a good chance   we can find it.
Whether we do or not, thank you   for... trying.       Date of birth. Tommy was born   February seventeenth...
I just got to have a little   something to jump start the   morning -- and a little something   else to shut down the night.
You have no medical need.
It's not a question of "need,"   darlin'. It's a matter of   survival.
Sorry.
Not to worry -- ol' Watosh will   scuffle along the best way he can.
How do I get a hold of the ol'   boy with the marinie face?
I beg your pardon?
What's his name... that android   fella.
Lieutenant Commander Data?
That's the one.
I'll let him know you want to see   him.
Much obliged. You sure are the   prettiest little doctor I ever   saw.
Much obliged.
Amazing. It's all right there.
Yes, ten generations of your   progeny.
Everyone I ever knew is dead.   Would you mind... I'd like to be   alone.
No, not at all.
You asked to see me.
I'm about to go out of my mind   for something to do. Sittin'   alone drinkin' don't get it. What   say you and me put together a   little party.
A celebration?
Naw... nothin' that fancy -- just   some folks, some suds, and some   sounds. Hell it ain't nothin'   but somethin' to do. Whatdeya   think?
I will ask the captain.
Great -- you do that...
Query. You do not seem to be   having as much difficulty   adjusting to your current   circumstances as are the others.

You mean being here -- on this tub   -- four hundred years from where   I started? Heck -- it's the same   dance, just a different tune.   You think anyone 'round here's   got a guitar I could borrow?
No, but the computer can replicate   such an instrument.
I was kind of hopin' to get one   while I still remember the chords.
Commander Data -- we are   approaching the Neutral Zone.   Report to the bridge.
I must leave.
What's this "Neutral Zone?"
A buffer between the Romulan   Empire and the Federation.
Why does that make me nervous?
I do not know.
We won't be inviting these   Romulans to our party, will we?
No, it would not be appropriate.
Captain's log, supplemental. We   have arrived at the edge of the   Neutral Zone. We will now have   an opportunity to learn firsthand   what happened to our distant   outposts.
There is nothing left of Outpost   Delta Zero-Five.
It must have been one hell of an   explosion.
Sensors indicate no evidence of   a conventional attack.
There is nothing left.
Can you determine what happened?
The outpost was not just   destroyed, it is as though some   great force just scooped it   off the face of the planet.
Could it have been a natural   phenomenon?
Insufficient information.
Geordi, set a course for the next   closest station.
Aye, sir.
I just can't believe this. When   that android fella said you could   duplicate this baby, I didn't   dream you'd do such a bang-up   job... You like country?
Excuse me?
Picking and strummin', son. What   about rock?
What about rock?
What's the matter, kid? You look   like you're staring at a ghost.
Well, sir, you were dead for over   three-hundred years...
How 'bout rhythm and blues? That   comes back every decade or so.
What was it like?... I mean, can   you remember...
What? Bein' dead? Not really,   but then again there wasn't a   whole lot happening.
Why did you do it? Was there   something left undone... something   you have to finish?
Nope. Just curiosity... Another   adventure... Simply wanted to see   what was going on.
We are approaching Tarod Nine.
The condition is identical,   Captain.
Everyone and everything is gone.

Captain, I strongly recommend that   we go to Red Alert. If the   Romulans have improved their   cloaking device, and we'd be fools   to think they haven't, we should   assume a more defensive posture.
I agree, Captain. I recommend   we go immediately to battle   stations.
I appreciate your concern and   advice, but this is not the time   for rash actions. We are still   investigating.
There are three other stations   in this sector which we need to   visit. Let's proceed in a calm   and orderly manner.
If not "battle stations," may I   at least bring the ship to Yellow   Alert?
Yes, Number One. That would be   prudent.
Thank you.
So, what is it that you want?
I've spent my career being able   to tell when the other guy's mouth   is dry. There is something going   on. Something serious. The   tension level on this ship has   jumped up.
Even if you're right, what can   we do about it? And besides,   these old boys don't need us to   tell them where the bear sits.
Lookie here what that young   fella made for me.
How did he do that?
He called it a pattern replication.   It plays real good, too.
I'm trying to tell you that there   is a situation developing on this   vessel which affects us, and all   you can talk about is that stupid   guitar!
These folks don't need us swimming   in their soup, so why don't you   just relax and let them do their   jobs?
That may be all right for you,   but I am not willing to allow my   fate to be decided by others.   I at least want to know what is   going on.
How are you planning to do that?
He needs help. I think he's   dying.
What the hell are you doing?
I'm going to find out what's going   on.
Ah... let's see.       Ah... I want to go to a... the...   ah...    (he shrugs; then to     himself:)   Where would the captain be?
Captain Picard is located on the   Main Bridge.
Then, take me to the Main Bridge.
Captain, my sensors indicate a   disturbance. It is large and   moving, but I cannot get a   positive lock nor can I get it   on the viewscreen.
Shields up.
Aye, sir.
Captain, I recommend we transfer   all power to phasers, and arm the   photon torpedos.
Wait. If that is a Romulan ship,   it will read our intent. We will   be forcing them to take a similar   posture. We are not out here to   engage in battles; we are explorers.
Captain, there is sufficient   evidence. Outposts have been   destroyed... Countless lives have   been lost.
I have a positive lock... It's   disengaging its cloaking device.
They are vulnerable for an instant   as they become visible.
Captain, this may be our only   chance.
I've lost them.
Are your sensors picking up   anything? You should be   detecting a disturbance.
Negative.
We wanted to know if they have   improved their cloaking device   -- I guess we have our answer.
They were trying to determine   our intent... They wanted to see   if we would fire.
Who the hell are they?
Get that man off the bridge...   now.
I'm not going anywhere.
Captain, they're back.
On screen.
Amazing. I never thought I would   ever see a Romulan ship -- not this   close.
The last encounter was decades   ago and cost thousands of lives.
I can believe that.
Stay calm, everyone.

Captain, these are Romulans -- they   are without honor. They killed   my parents in an attack on   Khitomer at a time when they were   supposed to be our allies. They   believe humans and Klingons are   a waste of skin, so inferior as   to be unworthy of any   consideration.
Lieutenant, keep your emotions   under control. Open hailing   frequencies.
Hailing frequencies open.
Romulan vessel, this is Captain   Jean-Luc Picard of the USS   Enterprise.
Sensors indicate all of their   systems are armed.
But they have not fired.
Let's try them again.
Hailing frequencies are still   open.
Romulan vessel, this is Captain   Jean-Luc Picard of the USS   Enterprise.
I am Commander Tebok.
You have crossed the Neutral Zone.   This is Federation territory.
It was necessary.
It could be viewed as an act of   aggression.
If our intent was aggression,   you would not now be here.
If we go to war, let us be sure   it is for the right reason. We   are here because our outposts,   which border the Neutral Zone,   were also attacked.
Destroyed in the exact same manner   as your own.
What right did they have to enter   Federation space?
Silence your dog, Captain.
Lieutenant Worf's question is   valid.
Even to ask such a question   implies that we need permission;   we do not.
Do you think we attacked your   outposts?
Once we realized the level of   destruction, we knew it could not   have been you.
Who is responsible?
They haven't a clue.
They're hoping you know, but   they're too arrogant to ask.
You're out of line, Mister.
Yes, but correct in his   assessment.
We do not know who is   responsible... Why entire   outposts on both sides were   carried off.
I would like to offer a proposal.
An alliance? Between the   Romulans and the Federation?
Nothing so grandiose -- just this.   Cooperation... whoever or whatever   did this is more powerful than   either of us.
Agreed.
On this one issue, and only if   it is convenient and something   we consider appropriate at the   time.

Captain Picard, because your   actions are those of a thoughtful   man who is neither rash nor easily   provoked, I tell you this. More   urgent matters have caused our   absence, and witness the results.   Outposts destroyed, evidence of   the Federation everywhere. We   have been negligent, but no more.
We have made some progress in our   relations... let's not ruin that   with unnecessary posturing.
Your presence is not wanted. Do   you understand my meaning? We   are back!
I think our lives just became a   lot more complicated.
Get him off my bridge.
I have found something.
I have been able to locate a   family living outside of   Indianapolis. The man's name is   Thomas Raymond.
That's my son's name. My son's   name is Tommy.
Computer -- let us see Thomas   Raymond.
Oh, my God... It's Donald...   that's my husband.
Actually, it's your great, great,   great, great, great grandson.
He's the spitting image.
I have his address. When you get   back to Earth, you could go and   see him.
But... I will still be out of   time. A relic.
Perhaps. But it's a place to   start. He is after all, family.
There's no denying that.
Here is what I propose. You can't   remain on the Enterprise. We have   arranged to rendezvous with the   USS Charleston, bound for Earth.   You will be delivered there.
And then what will happen to us?   There's no trace of my money -- my   office is gone -- what will I do?   How will I live?
This is the twenty-fourth century.   Those material needs no longer   exist.
Then what's the challenge?
To improve yourself... enrich   yourself. Enjoy it, Mister Offenhouse.
Well, one good thing -- since   everybody's forgotten everything   I ever did... it'll all be brand   spankin' new. Hell, I'll be a   bigger hit than I ever was.
Perhaps so, anything is possible.
What say, son -- you'd make a hell   of a sideman.
That offer does present a certain   fascination.
I have plotted a course to   intercept the Charleston, sir,   but they have informed me that   they will be making an extended   stop at Arloff Nine.
Your point, Lieutenant?
At warp eight, we could have   our guests at Starbase Thirty-Nine   Sierra in five days. It   would cut months off their   journey.
They will benefit from the   extended time. It will allow   them to acclimate before arriving   at Earth.
It's a pity we can't take them   ourselves. Having them on board   has been like a visit from the   past.
That would take us in the wrong   direction. Our mission is to go   forward and it has just begun.   Set velocity at warp six, Mister   La Forge.
Aye, sir... warp six.
There is still much to do... and   still so much to learn.       Mister La Forge... Engage.
